DataElement.preferredName: Hematopoietic Cell Graft Prior Infusion Procedure Process Method Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of any method used to process the hematopoietic cell product (graft) prior to infusion.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hematopoietic Cell Graft Prior Infusion Procedure Process
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)_Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body._Earlier in time or order._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion._A sequence of events which produces some outcome.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.):Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body.

Concepts.definition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)
Tissue or organ transplanted from a donor to a recipient.

Property.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.:A sequence of events which produces some outcome.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
A sequence of events which produces some outcome.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The mode or manner or orderly sequence of events of a process or procedure.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A sequence of events which produces some outcome._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To reduce in strength or concentration, especially by the addition of water.

Concepts.definition: To reduce in strength or concentration, especially by the addition of water.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Red blood cells. Mature erythrocytes are non-nucleated, biconcave disks containing hemoglobin whose function is to transport oxygen.: Reduced; made less in size or amount or degree.

Concepts.definition: A blood cell specialized for oxygen transport, having a high concentration of hemoglobin in the cytoplasm. They are biconcave, anucleate discs, with a 6-8um diameter in humans.
Made less in size or amount or degree.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The process of applying a solvent (e.g., water) or a solution (e.g., SSC/SDS) to a biomaterial or an array to remove impurities or unwanted compounds.

Concepts.definition: The process of applying a solvent (e.g., water) or a solution (e.g., SSC/SDS) to a biomaterial or an array to remove impurities or unwanted compounds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A process using centrifugation of whole blood to obtain a white blood cell layer highly enriched for neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes and progenitor cells.

Concepts.definition: A process using centrifugation of whole blood to obtain a white blood cell layer highly enriched for neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes and progenitor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.: Reduced; made less in size or amount or degree.

Concepts.definition: Plasma is the fluid (noncellular) portion of the circulating blood, as distinguished from the serum that is the fluid portion of the blood obtained by removal of the fibrin clot and blood cells after coagulation.
Made less in size or amount or degree.
